titleStmt.title: Study of a bcc multi-principal element alloy: Tensile and simple shear properties and underlying deformation mechanisms

affiliation.orgName: Institut de Recherche de Chimie Paris

analytic.title: Study of a bcc multi-principal element alloy: Tensile and simple shear properties and underlying deformation mechanisms

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: The impact of a concentrated solid solution on the deformation mechanisms of a bcc multi-principal elements alloy is investigated. The room temperature mechanical properties in tension and simple shear are studied on samples with controlled microstructure. The partition of the various stress components is performed, as well as the determination of the activation volumes and the analysis of the dislocation density and velocity. The study of the mechanical behavior is coupled to a complete TEM investigation. The alloy displays a high yield strength that is explained by a strong M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 2 impact of the short-range obstacles to the dislocation glide, with an enhancement of the effective stress due to the concentrated solid solution. The increase of the backstress is related to the formation of a heterogeneous dislocation structure, with dense dislocation bands acting as long-range obstacles. Deformation is controlled by screw dislocation glide. The a/2<111> screw dislocations are rectilinear, indicating a high lattice friction effect. Evolution of both dislocation velocity and density during multirelaxation transients suggests a low mobility. If activation volumes are consistent with a Peierls mechanism, other considerations rather head towards the hypothesis of a transitory regime where the solid solution could impact further the dislocation glide.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Multi-Principal Element Alloys (MPEAs), also called "High Entropy Alloys" (HEAs) are a family of materials that raised a lot of attention recently. Breaking with the traditional metallurgical concepts defining alloys as a mix between one principal element, and minor additions of solutes, MPEAs are based on several elements, with concentrations close to the equiatomicity [1]. Therefore, the notion of solvent and solute is lost. This new approach of alloy design has had much success lately, owing to some interesting first (mechanical) properties [2]. Most of the studied alloys belong to two main families: one with face centered cubic (fcc) or "fcc-matrix" structure, and the other one with body centered cubic (bcc) or a "bcc-matrix" structure, itself subdivided following the nature of the addition elements (transition metals or refractory ones). The Several studies report promising results for alloys belonging to the fcc family. They sometimes display greater properties than conventional fcc alloys with, for example, an increase of both the flow strength and the ductility with decreasing temperature [3][4][5].

Deformation occurs by dislocation glide and nano-twinning at cryogenic temperature [2,4]. The concentrated solid solution effect on the deformation mechanisms was investigated by calculation of the activation volumes [5,6], by TEM analyses [4] and by molecular simulations [7]. The results, among others, show that such alloys display lower activation volumes than classical coarse grains fcc alloys [6], and an unexpected temperature dependence of the yield strength [5]. Possible interpretations for such results involve a modification of the Peierls barrier of the alloy, as well as an important impact of the local fluctuations in composition.

Among the bcc family, the first published results on refractory compositions highlighted some promising high temperature properties, the tests being performed in compression mode on as-cast materials and under vacuum [8,9].

Possible control of the microstructure was afterwards demonstrated, using thermomechanical treatments [10,11]. Some uncommon features were already reported, as for example the case of the recrystallized quaternary bcc TiZrNbHf displaying a yield strength of 880 MPa in tension, at room temperature [12].

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
div.p: 4 Despite its high yield strength, the plastic deformation of the alloy seems rather conventional. A few studies considered the deformation mechanisms in such alloys. The TEM study by Couzinié et al. on the as-cast TiZrNbHfTa after compression testing suggested that screw dislocations glide controls the deformation, but did not highlight a feature that would be specific to such bcc MPEAs [13]. Investigation of the deformation mechanisms was carried out for the quaternary NbMoTaW MPEA, by nano-pillars compression tests [14]. By estimating the various components of the total stress characterizing the obstacles to dislocation motion for NbMoTaW and of pure Mofor comparison -a total stress twice as large as the one predicted by the theory is obtained in the case of the MPEA, when a good agreement is found in the case of Mo, leading to the hypothesis of a rather high contribution of the lattice resistance in the case of the MPEA. These results are supported by a recent study by Rao et al. simulating the dislocation glide in a non-refractory bcc MPEA based on the elements Co, Fe, Ni, and Ti [15]. The atomistic modeling evidences that the local composition fluctuations are responsible for an enhanced critical stress, since it is more than twofold compared to an "average medium" with the average properties of the elements composing the alloy, with respect to their concentration. This last study suggests that simple solid solution hardening models may be limited to describe the actual impact of a concentrated solid solution on a dislocation motion.

Overall, several hints already exist regarding a possible enhanced lattice friction effect in MPEAs compared to metals and traditional alloys, but, to the authors best knowledge, no in-depth experimental study exists on bcc MPEAs. Besides, other questions, such as the reason for having a superior yield strength compared to pure bcc metals tested in similar conditions at room temperature [16], remains unclear.

To investigate these aspects, a mechanical and microstructural study is proposed for a "model" MPEA with controlled microstructure. The equiatomic TiZrNbHfTa composition is selected as it already benefits from several papers reporting its mechanical properties [8,10,13,[17][18][19][20][21]. Besides, its bcc structure was already studied in the literature and no second phase was reported at room temperature, unlike some other bcc compositions [17,22]. This composition is considered here as a model alloy, to attempt to provide some insights on the deformation mechanisms of bcc MPEAs in general.

In this study, the deconvolution of the flow stress measured by cyclic simple shear tests is performed to obtain the evolution and respective contribution of the stress components, namely the effective stress and the backstress. Then, TEM samples are prepared from tensile strained samples, in order to characterize the deformation features at various plastic levels. Finally, single stress relaxation and multi-relaxation tests are performed, to access the activation volumes, characterizing the active deformation processes.

div.head: Sample preparation
div.formula: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 6
div.p: The equiatomic composition TiZrHfNbTa is prepared following a process described elsewhere [17]. Optimization of the microstructure is done by thermomechanical treatments. First, a cuboid with dimensions 5.5 mm x 7 mm x L max (maximal length available in the ingot) is cut out of the as-cast ingot by EDM.

For tensile testing, samples are cold-rolled with a thickness reduction of 60% and annealed at 1050°C for 2 hours under helium flow. They are then further cold-rolled with a thickness reduction of 65% followed by annealing at 1050°C for 4 hours. Each time the samples are introduced in the hot oven and were air quenched after the desired time. The two-step cold-rolling is performed to ensure that the sample deforms without cracking. The flat dog-bone shaped tensile testing samples are cut out of these thermomechanically treated pieces with a wire EDM. They are 0.8 mm thick and 20 mm long with a 4 mm gauge section.

A similar process is used to prepare shear stress specimen. As a larger thickness is needed, the as-cast pieces are cold-rolled with a thickness reduction of about 75-80% followed by annealing at 1100°C for 5 hours. Final samples have a parallelepiped shape with dimensions close to 11 mm in width and 15 mm in length, and a thickness of 1.3 mm. The length between the two jaws being 2 mm, the sheared surface is 30 mm 2 .

div.head: Mechanical testing
div.p: Tensile tests and single relaxation tests are done on an Instron machine controlled by an extensometer with 10 mm gauge length. The strain rate is 10 -4 s -1 . Multi-relaxation experiments are also performed on similar flat dog-bone specimen on a MTS 370.02

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
div.p: 7 hydraulic machine with 25kN capacity. The deformation is recorded using an extensometer, and a strain rate of 2.0 x 10 -4 s -1 is imposed. For all the tensile and single/multi-relaxation tests, the samples are strained with the tensile direction parallel to the rolling direction. The simple shear stress measurements are performed by use of home-made shear device mounted on a MTS machine. The sample is put between two jaws, one of them having translational movement relative to the other, imposing a shear strain rate of 10 -3 s -1 . The deformation is video-recorded and calculated with the variation of the angle of a black line drawn on the sample compared to its horizontal position prior to deformation. The sample is placed in the machine so that the rolling direction is along the shear axis as illustrated in Figure 1.

div.head: Microstructural characterization
div.p: The samples are mechanically polished on SiC papers and the final polishing step is done with OPS. Finally, a light etching with Kroll agent is done on the surface.

EBSD is performed to measure the grain size, using a Zeiss Merlin scanning electron microscope operating at 20kV, equipped with an Oxford EBSD camera. The camera is equipped with forward scatter detectors (FSD) that are used to image the surface.
The average grain size in the tensile testing specimen and in the shear tested specimen are 31 µm and 65 µm, respectively.

Post-mortem microstructure analyses are performed by Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) on 3 mm diameter discs polished down manually to 100 µm and then twin-jet electropolished using an electrolyte composed of HF/H 2 SO 4 in methanol,

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D
div.p: ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 8 at -35°C. The tensile axis is identified on the TEM samples and oriented parallel to the tilt axis of the microscope. Determination of the grain orientation with respect to the tensile axis, and consequently the calculation of the Schmid factor (SF) is thus allowed.
The observations are performed on a JEOL 2000EX TEM. Dislocations are indexed using the classical extinction criterion. Trace analysis is achieved using the Stereo-proj software [23].

div.head: Stress partitioning
div.p: The stress partition is performed on each cycle of the shear stress measurements (Figure 2a). The data is extracted following a procedure first proposed by Cottrell [24]. This partition is based on the principle that the stress ߬ ௫ can be divided into two main contributions ߬ ௫ = ߬ + ܺ (Equation 1)

where ߬ is the effective stress and ܺ is the internal stress or backstress. The former is the stress required to activate the dislocation glide and characterizes the short distance interactions; it stands by definition for the elastic deformation of the sample; the later is related to the long-distance interactions between the gliding dislocation and the microstructure (including precipitates, grain boundaries…). The contribution of the short range obstacles is isotropic and visualized as a circle centered in C, with CD the radius of the elastic domain (Figure 2b). In contrast, the backstress ܺ corresponds to the translation of this elastic domain and can be therefore seen as a kinematic hardening.
div.formula: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT9
div.p: The partition is performed as illustrated in Figure 2b, and an offset of 0.1% is taken to determine the point D, or reverse yield strength (see dashed line).

div.head: Determination of the activation volumes
div.p: The signature of the deformation mechanism is first assessed through the calculation of the apparent activation volumes V a * .

Their determination is performed through simple relaxation tests, following a procedure detailed elsewhere [13]. Only the first 200 sec of the relaxation are considered, for which we suppose that the internal stress does not evolve. The stress variation during the relaxation is fitted with the classical logarithmic law ∆ߪሺ‫ݐ‬ሻ =

where T is the temperature of the test, k is the Boltzmann constant and c is a time constant. Regarding the scaling factor M, a value M=2.75 typical of pencil glide is considered, as suggested in several other works [13,25,26].

To further separate the contributions of the mobile dislocation density ߩ and velocity ߭, both contributing to the plastic strain rate ߛሶ in the Orowan equation ߛሶ = ߙߩ ܾ߭, where ܾ is the Burgers vector and ߙ is a geometric coefficient, the physical activation volumes are then calculated by repeated multi-relaxation tensile tests (Figure 3). In these tests, series of 5 relaxations of 30 seconds each are performed to ensure a purely effective stress evolution during the relaxation [27,28]. The sample is first loaded at constant strain rate to a set stress ߪ . The five relaxations are then performed, and in between each 30-seconds relaxations, the sample is elastically re- 2)

div.head: Stress partitioning
div.p: Figure 4 gives the evolution of the involved stresses (Equation 1) with cumulative strain during several simple shear cyclic tests (all compiled in this plot). For an easier comparison, the various contributions are normalized by the experimentally measured shear modulus of 30 GPa. The latter is in good agreement with the C 44 value of 28 GPa obtained by Brillouin light scattering method on the same alloy [18].

The results highlight mainly two major trends: firstly, the effective stress takes high values and is also almost strain-independent; indeed, ߬ goes from about 450 MPa at the beginning of the deformation to about 470 at the end, which represents between 70 and 90% of the total stress. Secondly, the initially small backstress evolves the same way as ߬ ௫ with strain. It increases from 50 MPa to about 150 MPa during the first 50% of accumulated deformation approximately, and then saturates for the rest of the deformation. Hardening of the complex solid solution is also mainly related to internal stresses, i.e. kinematical effect from a mechanical point of view.

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D
Deformation microstructures
div.p: The monitoring of the deformation mechanisms is performed with (EBSD-)SEM and TEM observations of samples taken from tensile specimen deformed at a set strain. The overall tensile curve is represented in Figure 5. The material displays an elastic modulus of 92 GPa, a yield strength at 0.2% of 940 MPa, a sharp elastic to plastic transition and a uniform elongation larger than 15%. The normalized work-hardening, plotted in red versus the plastic strain in the inset of Figure 5 shows three phases. The first one corresponds to a strong decrease of ߠ ߤ ⁄ , the second one to a stabilization around 0.030 and a final decrease for a plastic deformation larger to about 0.10.

div.head: Figure 11
div.p: The evolution of the mobile dislocation density and velocity can be obtained from the ߚ parameter (equations 5 and 6). They are represented as a function of time in Figure 12, for the five relaxations of a transient.

div.head: Figure 12
div.p: The continuous evolution of ߩ ߩ ⁄ is due to the absence of microstructural changes between the end of a relaxation and the beginning of the next one, since the reloading of the sample is purely elastic. Overall, the exhaustion of the mobile dislocations is quite low and does not evolve much during the multi-relaxation process: only 12% of the initial mobile dislocations are exhausted. The evolution of the dislocation velocity evidences a fast drop down to almost zero during each relaxation.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: The multi-scale coupling between mechanical testing and microstructural analysis of the TiZrNbHfTa solid solution gives some clear indications on the plastic behavior of such multi-component alloy. The main results could be summarized as follows and will be discussed in the next paragraphs:

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D
div.p: (1) the main component of the yield and flow stress is the effective one -i.e. related to short range interactions between gliding dislocations and the microstructure -and is strain-independent;
(2) kinematical hardening is clearly highlighted;
(3) values of apparent and also physical activation volumes are compatible with a Peierls deformation mechanism;
(4) weak exhaustion of the mobile dislocations is observed during relaxation tests.
Dislocations are barely mobile in these tests;
(5) screw dislocations aligned along <111> directions are observed in the entire range of deformation. These dislocations are patterned in bands whose density increases with strain;
(6) numerous debris are observed in these bands.

div.head: Stress partitioning: contribution of the short-and long-range obstacles to the mechanical properties
div.p: As obtained by the stress partitioning, the effective stress extrapolated to the onset of plastic deformation contributes for about 90% of the yield strength of the alloy and characterizes short range obstacles to dislocation motion, i.e. lattice friction and solid solution combined effects. This means that the substantial yield strength of this alloy is essentially due to the stress required to extract the dislocation from its local environment.
The long-distance obstacles are characterized by the internal stress which is, for the yield strength, almost negligible compared to the effective stress.

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 18
div.p: As highlighted in Figure 4, the effective stress is strain-independent; and keeps high levels during the deformation process, which corroborates the hindering of dislocation glide by local obstacles. In this regard, TEM observations support the hypothesis of strong local obstacles. This result is in good agreement with the results of Zou et al. on
NbMoTaW nanopillars [14], that point out that the short-range obstacles play a key role in the deformation.

In profile analysis, after compression testing on the same solid solution [13,19]. Therefore, the local stresses that must be overcome by a gliding dislocation remain high during the whole deformation.

Contrary to the effective stress, the evolution of the backstress X is strain-dependent and follows the same trend as the total shear stress τ max (Figure 4). In consequence, work hardening is mainly related to the evolution of this component. The coupled increase of the dislocation density and bands formation contributes to the formation of a composite structure made of dislocation walls and dislocation-free zones. The heterogeneous microstructure puts up long-range interaction field opposing gliding dislocations, which can explain the increase of the backstress i.e. the kinematical hardening.

div.head: Discussion of active deformation mechanisms: dislocation properties and hardening phenomenon in bcc refractory solid solution
M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
div.p: From our observations, it clearly appears that screw dislocations with b=a/2<111>

Burgers vector control the plastic deformation in the equimolar solid solution. The rectilinear aspect of the screw dislocations indicates a strong lattice friction, with dislocations anchored in the Peierls valleys. Dislocation patterning further evidences that a heterogeneous structure falls into place during the first stages of the deformation.
This step is followed by an increase of the dislocation density, with dislocations filling the empty areas until a rather homogeneous structure is obtained at the end of the deformation.

Finally, several debris (loops, dipoles) can be observed in the dense bands as illustrated in Figure 8b. The appearance of such defects will be discussed further, to help interpret the possible deformation mechanisms.

The observation of straight screw dislocation segments echoes the evolution of the dislocation density and velocity (Figure 12), which evidences that the dislocation glide seems indeed rather uneasy in this alloy: along a relaxation, the density of mobile dislocations does not decrease much, and their velocity quickly drops down to almost zero (Figure 12). A fast blocking of dislocations or obstacles to cross slip could explain such a trend.

If for some grains, {110} and {112} glide planes were unambiguously determined; in most cases, however, the determination of the glide plane is unclear. This suggests that both cases -glide on {110}-or {112}-planes -are possible, and intermediate glide between both planes (unclear glide plane) as well.
In bcc structures, the screw dislocation core in its ground state is dissociated in the three In bcc solid solution with substitutional elements the situation is quite different.

The main trends could be described as follows. With alloying additions, the critical resolved shear stress (CRSS) and the athermal temperature are both generally shifted to higher values (case of softening will not be discussed here). The hump in the CRSS=f(T) is no longer always observed, although it was still reported for some cases such as Fe and Nb based alloys [30,32]. Stress and activation volumes discontinuities are shifted towards higher temperatures and effective stresses, respectively [32,33]. Hardening effects are often described considering thermal and athermal components ( * and respectively) of the flow stress, even if some care must be taken concerning athermal conditions (stress and temperature), which are never unambiguously determined. Two possibilities are then described in the literature: either hardening only affects -especially in the high temperature regime -or both * and [32,[34][35][36]. As found in the literature, hardening has more often been associated to the increase of , which usually evolves proportionally to the alloy composition in the high temperature region (plateau
div.formula: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT22
div.p: region) [36]. Such stress seems well-fitted to the Labusch model with an observed linear evolution of the strengthening with a misfit parameter including the size and modulus effects. This latter aspect of the solid solution hardening is still a controversial point [34,37,38]. If such hardening models considering the interaction between edge dislocations and solute elements are well suited for fcc structures, it was pointed out in recent work that the situation in bcc structure is more complex for two main reasons. Firstly, screw dislocations -and not edge ones -control the plasticity from low temperatures to the athermal one; secondly, the interaction force between a screw defect and a solute atom is lower than non-screw parts [39,40]. In that case, deformation is then controlled by the probable athermal by-passing of super jogs and seems to be the origin of solute hardening in iron based alloys [41]. athermal contribution could also be added to other effects related to misfit and modulus effects already described [21]. In this regard, the latter effect has to be considered as the shear modulus of the MPEA is close to the one of the room temperature hcp elements (Ti, Zr, Hf) but significantly lower than those of bcc metals (Nb, Ta). Such low value (30 GPa) should affect dislocation properties and thereby mechanical behavior.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: This paper provides an in-depth study of the deformation mechanisms of a quinary bcc MPEA at room temperature. To achieve reproducible results, all the analyses are performed on samples with recrystallized microstructure. The analysis is done both on a mechanical side (stress partitioning, calculation of the activation volumes) and on a microstructural side, with the TEM analysis of the deformation features. The principal results are summarized below.

div.head: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT

div.p: • A high yield strength is obtained by uniaxial tensile testing. Stress partitioning evidences that it is linked to the strong effect of short distance obstacles on gliding dislocations, with a major impact of the solid solution.
• The work-hardening occurring in the alloy is mostly due to the formation of a microstructure with dense bands, acting as long range obstacles.

• The deformation is controlled by dislocation glide. The dislocations are mostly screw and rectilinear. Their mobility is low, as confirmed by the evolution of the dislocation density and velocity along multi-relaxation series.

• Calculation of the activation volumes and TEM observations (strong lattice friction) tend to indicate that Peierls mechanisms are active. However, the classical kink-pair mechanism could not explain alone the experimental values.
The hypothesis of a transitory regime with some influence of the pinning is highly suggested.

A concept that has already been suggested is that the concentration fluctuation, due to the statistic repartition of the different elements onto the lattice position, would favor the notion of an "effective medium" over that of a classical solid solution. In good agreement with the results of Rao et al. [15], this study rather concludes that the solid solution play a significant role, probably related to the local fluctuations impacting the dislocation core configuration.

figure.figDesc: matrix" term refers to alloys that are not single phase, and contain a second phase or precipitates embedded in a bcc or fcc solid solution phase.

The apparent activation volumes are calculated for each relaxation of the series following the logarithmic law given above. The physical activation volumes can then be obtained since related to the apparent ones by the parameter ߗ following ߗ = ೌ * * (Equation

{110} planes, corresponding to a sessile configuration. Dislocation glide thus requires M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 20 constriction of the dislocation core, and subsequent nucleation and propagation of a pair of kinks. Such processes are thermally activated, hence the classical temperature and strain rate sensitivity. The {112} glide could then be explained as an average glide on the possible {110} glide planes, as a result of a spread dislocation core. Possible hardening mechanisms in the MPEA Based on these observations, the determination of the process by which dislocations move can be studied. First of all, in order to understand the deformation processes and with the desire to make a relevant comparison with existing classical bcc materials, a quick overview of the plasticity of such bcc metals and solid solution alloys under mechanical solicitations is provided. In highly pure bcc metals, the situation is relatively well-known and described by two temperature-stress dependent regimes. In the low temperature regime (i.e. high stress range) the yield strength strongly depends on temperature. Activation volumes are generally low (about one ten b 3 ) and deformation mechanisms are controlled by screw defects subjected to Peierls friction force and could be associated to different saddle configurations [30]. One is related to the sessileglissile transformation of screw non-planar dislocation cores with the possible existence of a metastable state leading to some specific mechanisms at very low temperatures describing the jerky motion of screw dislocations over several Peierls hills (locking-unlocking mechanism) [30]. In the high temperature regime (i.e. low stress range), the locking-unlocking mechanism becomes athermal at a relatively low temperature (approximately 100K for Fe and Mo, 150K for Nb) and the kink effective with dislocations moving uniformly, with jumps corresponding to the distance between Peierls valleys in the glide plane[31]. This change explains the presence of a hump in the = ሺሻ plot and also the discontinuity in the evolution of the activation volume with stress for many bcc metals[31]. Finally, athermal condition is achieved at a temperature for which dislocations are no more impeded by short-range obstacles i.e. the friction force exerted on screw defects is low enough to consider that dislocation mobility is independent of dislocation orientation.

figure.head: 24 The
figure.figDesc: , there is a lack of information concerning the effective hardening mechanisms in bcc alloys at the nanoscopic scale. The most complete study investigates iron solid solutions with high concentration of alloying elements (Si, Cr)[41]. The macroscopic evolution of the CRSS with temperature in concentrated alloys compared to pure iron can be explained with the help of TEM straining in-situ tests. In solid solutions at low temperatures (T<250K), a steady motion of screw dislocations due to the classical kink-pair mechanism is observed.Pinning is highlighted but is not a barrier to dislocation motion in this regime.However, above a transition temperature (close to 300 K but below the athermal one), a change in dislocation motion is evidenced, with strong local pinning of the dislocations at super jogs. In the case of the present MPEA, it is therefore important to identify in which regime is standing the solid solution at room temperature to better identify the possible thermally activated mechanisms. The situation is however not simple as M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT no clear data exists on the evolution of stress with temperature on controlled microstructures for this composition, the reported continuous decrease of yield stress from 293 to 1473K being most likely due to diffusion assisted flow mechanisms [8]. An estimation of whether or not the alloy falls into the high temperature "like" regime (making an analogy with pure metals) can be made based on the activation volumes. In this regime, for which the rate controlling mechanism is supposed to be the double-kink nucleation, the critical configuration is a described by a pair of well-separated kinks [39]. The activation volume is given considering the elastic interaction between the kinks (Coulomb elastic interaction): the distance between two atomic rows, quantified for each considered plan, b is the Burger vector, is the shear modulus and the resolved effective shear stress. If one considers that = * , using equation 7, a critical shear stress for such mechanism = ૡ * is obtained. An average activation volume of 40b 3 (in the first steps of the plastic deformation) with = √ and a = 340.7 pm [13], a shear modulus = GPa, and kink heights of {} = √ in a {110} plane and {} = √ in a {112} plane were used. A low critical shear stress {} ≈ . MPa is found for glide in the {110} plane, and {} ≈ MPa is obtained for glide on {112}. Comparatively the average CRSS can be estimated based on the yield strength, which is usually considered as made of several terms [5]: = + + + + different terms correspond to the contribution of the hardening by forest dislocations ( ), the precipitates ( ), the grain boundaries strengthening (socalled Hall-Petch effect) ( ), the friction stress ( ) and the solid solution effect ( ). As the solid solution effect may affect the lattice friction, the last two terms are not dissociated, and are considered as one single contribution characterizing these short-range interactions . Based on the recrystallized state of the alloy it is supposed that ‫‪ሻ‬ۯ۳۾ۻ‪ሺ‬‬ is negligible. Furthermore, the absence of precipitates allows to exclude the contribution of . In a first approximation, the contribution of the grain boundaries could be found in the /√ term of the Hall-Petch equation. For the considered grain size of approximately 30 µm, and using the value of k from the literature [11], ‫‪ሻ‬ۯ۳۾ۻ‪ሺ‬‬ is estimated to 45 MPa. Therefore, ‫‪ሻ‬ۯ۳۾ۻ‪ሺ‬‬ is close to 895 MPa leading to an average CRSS around 325 MPa, considering a scale factor of 2.75. Such a high stress is incompatible with a high temperature regime mechanism in which double kink pair nucleation is the rate controlling step. Furthermore, the model based on Coulomb's interaction is probably not valid for this stress suggesting that other mechanisms are active leading to a value of physical activation volume close to 40b 3 . It should also be mentioned that 40b 3 is particularly high for most of niobium and tantalum based alloys [35,42] in this temperature and stress range with the exception of concentrated niobiummolybdenum and niobium-tungsten [32,43]. In such cases, combined effects due to changes in lattice friction coupled to long-range solution hardening are proposed to explain the results. Interestingly Statham and al. suggest a reduction in the mobility of the edge-screw ratio due to the previous coupling [32]. M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D The fact that several dipoles and loops are observed in our study during dislocation patterning could indicate an inclination towards pinning. Solid solution atoms (individual or more probably clusters) may reduce the motion of lateral kinks and cross kinks due to the non-planar screw dislocation core may lead to the formation of highly hardenable (super)jogs [44]. However, the impact of pinning differs based on the stress or temperature regime. Indeed, if low temperatures only decrease the dislocation velocity due to the segmentation of screws by pinning points, the increase of temperature reduces Peierls stresses and dislocation bend up to the point where there is no pure screw segment left for kink-pair nucleation.

hypotheses are in line with recent atomistic simulations performed on a random bcc multicomponent alloy [15]. Authors evidence four major points: screw dislocation core strongly varies along the line, probably based on the local chemical environment; high calculated CRSS due to local fluctuations of composition; strong hardening due to the frequent formation of super jogs by cross-kinks at misfit strain centers; high kink pair activation energy in the model random MPEA; reduced mobility of edge dislocations.In the present study, it appears reasonable to suggest that the presence of debris in the microstructure is related to the formation of super jogs at room temperature.Consequently, the kink mobility is disrupted and controlled by the short-range interactions with pinning agents. The intrinsic nature of these agents is still unknown in the MPEA and would deserve a lot of attention in future studies. are obstacles surmountable by thermal activation, only large clusters of atoms could significantly impede kink motion, reduce the dislocation motion and hence induce the formation of super jogs[45]. Such a reduction of dislocation velocity could be consistent with the results obtained by analysis of the multi-relaxation results (Figure12). Finally, strong hardening is the consequence of the defects by-passing defects by screw dislocations and contributes significantly to athermal part of the strength as the process requires high stresses. Such
the whole range of deformation, observations of rectilinear screw dislocations clearly

note.p: suggest that plasticity is only controlled by dislocation glide in accordance with previous observations by Couzinié et al. and Dirras et al. by TEM and X-rays line

div.p: Acknowledgements: The authors gratefully acknowledge Daniel Caillard (CEMES, CNRS) for fruitful discussions and exchanges about screw dislocation mobility in bcc alloys.
